case_name: Legal Representatives of Lalji Jetha and Kanji Jetha v. Respondents Nos. 1 and 2

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 9, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in Civil Appeal No. 2 of 1956.

The appellants then applied for a certificate in the High Court and on its refusal obtained special leave from this Court and that is how this appeal has come up before us for hearing and final disposal.

the contention that the said declaration operated as res judicata against the respondents and prevented them from asserting that the property was theirs was number tenable At the moment when it was passed the possession of the purchaser was adverse, and the declaration that the property had been made subject to a trust disposition, and therefore ought number to have been seized, did number disturb or affect the quality of his possession, it merely emphasised the fact that it was adverse.

anchor.surface_text: that their possession was adverse, that the said decree did number affect Laljis title, ripened as a result of adverse possession, that the present suit ought to have been filed before 1942 and therefore a preliminary decree for redemption could only be passed against Kanji.

concepts.interpretation: Possession ripens into title after statutory period if adverse.
concepts.unlisted_description: Doctrine that continuous hostile possession for statutory period ripens into ownership.

anchor.surface_text: if by common consent the mortgagors and the mortgagees agree to put an end to the mortgagees estate by the mortgagors executing a deed of sale and the mortgagees assert their right by ownership under such a sale, even if such sale were to be declared to be invalid their possession becomes adverse and such adverse possession ripens into a title if it continues for the statutory period.

concepts.interpretation: Mortgagee's possession becomes adverse upon sale extinguishing mortgage, even if sale invalid.
concepts.unlisted_description: Conversion of mortgagee possession to adverse via sale deed.

anchor.surface_text: the observation made by the High Court that possession of Kanji and Lalji was at numberpoint of time adverse is clearly contrary to the decision of the Privy Council and the two decisions of the High Court of Bombay which were binding on them.

concepts.interpretation: High Court erred; possession can be adverse at some point post-sale.

anchor.surface_text: Kanji and Lalji being in a fiduciary position, their possession was number adverse as against respondents 1 and 2. Therefore their suit for redemption cannot be said to be barred even though the statutory period had expired.

concepts.interpretation: Not adverse against prior specific performance claimants if purchaser with notice holds as fiduciary.
concepts.unlisted_description: Qualified by fiduciary duty to prior contracting party.

anchor.surface_text: But paragraph 2 of s. 40 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882 in clear terms lays down that where a third. person is entitled to the benefit of an obligation arising out of contract and annexed to the ownership of immovable property, but number amounting to an interest therein, such right or obligation may be enforced against a transferee of the property affected thereby, but number against a transferee for consideration and without numberice of the right or obligation number against such property in his hands.

concepts.interpretation: Right from prior contract enforceable against subsequent transferee with notice.

concepts.unlisted_description: Enforcement of contractual obligations annexed to property against transferees with notice.

anchor.surface_text: Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act in terms provides that such a contract of sale does number create as in English law any equitable estate in the immovable property which is the subject matter of the contract.

concepts.interpretation: Contract for sale does not create equitable estate or interest in property.
concepts.unlisted_description: No equitable estate from sale contract.

anchor.surface_text: But as aforesaid, the contract creates an obligation which is recognised by section 3 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877 and section 91 of the Indian Trusts Act, 1882. Section 3 of the Specific Relief Act defines an obligation as including every duty enforceable by law and a trustee as including every person holding expressly, by implication or constructively a fiduciary character. Illustration g to that section reads as follows A buys certain land from B, with numberice that B has already contracted to buy it. A is a trustee, within the meaning of this Act for B, of the land so bought.

concepts.interpretation: Obligation includes duty enforceable by law; purchaser with notice of prior contract is constructive trustee.
concepts.unlisted_description: Definition of obligation and trustee including constructive trustee for prior purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: This principle is embodied in section 91 of the Indian Trusts Act which lays down that where a person acquires property with numberice that another person has entered into an existing contract affecting that property, of which specific performance could be enforced, the former must hold the property for the benefit of the latter to the extent necessary to give effect to the contract.

concepts.interpretation: Purchaser with notice of prior enforceable specific performance contract holds property as trustee for prior party.
concepts.unlisted_description: Constructive trust for benefit of prior contracting party against noticee purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that as mortgagees-in-possession Kanji and Lalji derived their title to possession through the mortgagors and by virtue of their rights under the said mortgage. They were entitled therefore to continue to be in possession under the said mortgage and so long as it subsisted. By merely asserting rights of ownership in the said shops they could number convert their possession as mortgagees and unilaterally alter their lawful possession as mortgagees into possession hostile to the mortgagors.

issues.text: Whether the suit for redemption and possession is barred by limitation due to adverse possession by Kanji and Lalji since the execution of the sale deed dated September 10, 1930

anchor.surface_text: In his written statement Lalji alleged that since he was not a party to the earlier suit the said decree was not binding upon him, that as a result of the said deed of sale dated September 10, 1930 he and Kanji became absolute owners and the right of redemption by the mortgagors and those claiming through them became extinguished, that Kanji had by an oral sale transferred his right, title and interest to him and therefore he was the absolute owner, and lastly that as a result of the sale deed he acquired ownership, that his possession was to the knowledge of the plaintiffs and was adverse against them and therefore the suit was barred by limitation.

By merely asserting rights of ownership in the said shops they could not convert their possession as mortgagees and unilaterally alter their lawful possession as mortgagees into possession hostile to the mortgagors.

Kanji and Lalji being in a fiduciary position, their possession was not adverse as against respondents 1 and 2. Therefore their suit for redemption cannot be said to be barred even though the statutory period had expired.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of Mr. Sarjooprasad, however, was that the said decree for specific performance cannot effect the adverse nature of possession of Kanji and Lalji as even when respondents 1 and 2 obtained the deed of sale from the court in April 1947 Kanji was number made one of the conveying parties...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t effect the adverse nature of possession of Kanji and Lalji as even when respondents 1 and 2 obtained the deed of sale from the companyrt in April 19

arguments.court_reasoning: No difference; attesting made aware; possession not adverse due to fiduciary

holdings.text: A mortgagee in possession cannot convert their possession into adverse possession merely by asserting ownership; it requires a sale by the mortgagor to end the mortgage estate.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that as mortgagees-in-possession Kanji and Lalji derived their title to possession through the mortgagors and by virtue of their rights under the said mortgage. They were entitled therefore to continue to be in possession under the said mortgage and so long as it subsisted. By merely asserting rights of ownership in the said shops they could not convert their possession as mortgagees and unilaterally alter their lawful possession as mortgagees into possession hostile to the mortgagors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mortgage possession derives from mortgagor; unilateral assertion does not alter character.

holdings.text: A sale by mortgagor to mortgagee ends the mortgage estate, vesting absolute ownership and converting possession to that of an owner, even if the sale is voidable; such possession ripens into title after statutory period.

anchor.surface_text: But it is a well settled proposition that a mortgagor can sell the mortgaged property to his mortgagee and thus put the mortgagees estate to an end and thereafter all the right, title and interest in the property would vest in the mortgagee. Such a sale would be valid and binding as between them and henceforth the character of possession as a mortgagee would be converted into possession as an absolute owner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled proposition supported by precedents; sale valid between parties, possession character changes regardless of voidability.

holdings.text: A decree declaring a sale invalid or property subject to trust does not disturb the adverse quality of the purchaser's possession; it emphasizes its adversity.

anchor.surface_text: the contention that the said declaration operated as res judicata against the respondents and prevented them from asserting that the property was theirs was not tenable At the moment when it was passed the possession of the purchaser was adverse, and the declaration that the property had been made subject to a trust disposition, and therefore ought not to have been seized, did not disturb or affect the quality of his possession, it merely emphasised the fact that it was adverse.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council and Bombay HC precedents; decree does not factually interrupt possession.

holdings.text: The High Court's observation that possession of Kanji and Lalji was at no point adverse is contrary to Privy Council and Bombay High Court decisions.

anchor.surface_text: the observation made by the High Court that possession of Kanji and Lalji was at no point of time adverse is clearly contrary to the decision of the Privy Council and the two decisions of the High Court of Bombay which were binding on them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly applies binding precedents overlooked by lower court.

holdings.text: Rights under s.40(2) TPA allow enforcement of contractual obligations annexed to property against transferees with notice, but not bona fide purchasers without notice.

anchor.surface_text: But paragraph 2 of s. 40 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882 in clear terms lays down that where a third. person is entitled to the benefit of an obligation arising out of contract and annexed to the ownership of immovable property, but not amounting to an interest therein, such right or obligation may be enforced against a transferee of the property affected thereby, but not against a transferee for consideration and without notice of the right or obligation not against such property in his hands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of statute; contract creates enforceable obligation, not interest.

holdings.text: A contract for sale does not create an equitable estate per s.54 TPA, but creates an obligation under s.3 Specific Relief Act and s.91 Indian Trusts Act, making a purchaser with notice a constructive trustee.

anchor.surface_text: Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act in terms provides that such a contract of sale does not create as in English law any equitable estate in the immovable property which is the subject matter of the contract. But as aforesaid, the contract creates an obligation which is recognised by section 3 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877 and section 91 of the Indian Trusts Act, 1882.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definitions and illustrations; purchaser holds for prior party's benefit.

holdings.text: Kanji and Lalji, having notice of prior contract, hold in fiduciary position; their possession not adverse against respondents 1 and 2; redemption suit not barred by limitation despite statutory period expiry.

anchor.surface_text: Kanji and Lalji being in a fiduciary position, their possession was not adverse as against respondents 1 and 2. Therefore their suit for redemption cannot be said to be barred even though the statutory period had expired.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s.40 TPA, Trusts Act s.91; fiduciary duty prevents adversity to specific claimants.

holdings.text: Kanji attesting the 1947 conveyance deed as witness does not alter the fiduciary conclusion or make possession adverse; he was aware of the rights.

anchor.surface_text: But that would not, in our view, make any difference in the conclusion that as between Kanji and Lalji on the one hand and respondents 1 and 2 on the other the possession of the former could not be adverse and therefore there was no question of the suit of respondents 1 and 2 for redemption being barred by limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical extension of fiduciary duty; attestation confirms notice.

precedents.citation: Subbaiya Pandaram v. Mohamad Mustapha Maracayar 50 I.A. 295 at 299

anchor.surface_text: In Subbaiya Pandaram v. Mohamad Mustapha Maracayar 1  a suit was brought by the appellant in 1913 against the respondents for possession of immovable property which had been dedicated to the endowment of a chattaram by deeds of trust executed in 1890 by the appellants grandfather.

precedents.case_name: Subbaiya Pandaram v. Mohamad Mustapha Maracayar
precedents.cited_proposition: declaration that the property had been made subject to a trust disposition did not disturb or affect the quality of adverse possession, it merely emphasised that it was adverse
precedents.cited_holding: the declaration that the property had been made subject to a trust disposition, and therefore ought not to have been seized, did not disturb or affect the quality of his possession, it merely emphasised the fact that it was adverse

anchor.surface_text: This decision was followed in Dagadabhai v. Sakharam 2  where the High Court of Bombay held that if a decree for possession in plaintiffs favour does not in fact result in the defendant giving up possession of the property or having possession of the property taken from him, it cannot be said that it had interrupted possession nor can it in law affect the nature of the possession, unless it does so in fact.

precedents.cited_proposition: a decree for possession does not interrupt adverse possession unless possession is actually given up or taken
precedents.cited_holding: if a decree for possession in plaintiffs favour does not in fact result in the defendant giving up possession of the property or having possession of the property taken from him, it cannot be said that it had interrupted possession nor can it in law affect the nature of the possession, unless it does so in fact

anchor.surface_text: See also Bogilal v. Ratanlal .  3  The observation made by the High Court that possession of Kanji and Lalji was at no point of time adverse is clearly contrary to the decision of the Privy Council and the two decisions of the High Court of Bombay which were binding on them.

precedents.cited_proposition: decree does not interrupt adverse possession unless effective in fact

precedents.citation: Lala Durga Prasad Anr., v. Lala Deep Chand Ors. 1954 S.C.R. 360

anchor.surface_text: In Lala Durga Prasad Anr., v. Lala Deep Chand Ors.  1 - this Court after considering these provisions observed that in spite of the existence of a previous contract of sale, a sale to a subsequent purchaser even with notice is not void but voidable at the instance of the party agreeing to purchase under a previous contract and except for the obligation arising from section 91 of the Trusts Act and paragraph 2 of section 40 of the Transfer of Property Act the title to the property would pass from the vendor to the subsequent transferee.

precedents.case_name: Lala Durga Prasad v. Lala Deep Chand
precedents.cited_proposition: sale to subsequent purchaser with notice of prior contract is voidable, not void, but subject to obligations under Trusts Act s.91 and TPA s.40
precedents.cited_holding: in spite of the existence of a previous contract of sale, a sale to a subsequent purchaser even with notice is not void but voidable at the instance of the party agreeing to purchase under a previous contract

precedents.citation: Gafur v. Bhikaji Govind Ors. 26 I.L.R. Bom. 159

anchor.surface_text: In Gafur v. Bhikaji Govind Ors.  2  the facts were almost similar to the facts in the present case. The first defendant there had entered into an agreement dated June 25, 1895 to sell certain land to the plaintiff.

precedents.cited_proposition: purchaser with notice of prior agreement holds property for benefit of prior purchaser to give effect to the contract
precedents.cited_holding: the second defendant had purchased the said land in December 1895 with notice of the earlier agreement of June 1895 with the plaintiff. The High Court held that the plaintiff was entitled to possession and as the second defendant had purchased with notice of the plaintiffs contract he held the property for the benefit of the plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: In Sathiraju v. Venkanna 1  the High Court of Madras similarly observed that as a result of s. 91 of the Trusts Act the natural result of a person purchasing a property with notice of a prior contract in another persons favour is that the purchaser holds the property for the benefit of the latter to the extent necessary to give effect to the contract.

precedents.cited_proposition: purchaser with notice of prior contract holds property as trustee for prior contracting party under Trusts Act s.91
precedents.cited_holding: as a result of s. 91 of the Trusts Act the natural result of a person purchasing a property with notice of a prior contract in another persons favour is that the purchaser holds the property for the benefit of the latter to the extent necessary to give effect to the contract

precedents.citation: Appa Rao v. Veeranna A.I.R. 1953 Mad. 409

anchor.surface_text: See also Appa Rao v. Veeranna .  2  It is thus clear that though the sale dated September 10, 1930 in favour of Kanji and Lalji was not void but voidable at the instance of respondents 1 and 2 by reason of their earlier contract

precedents.cited_proposition: decree for specific performance must direct subsequent purchaser to join in execution of conveyance

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out in Lala Durga Prasads 3  case the logical course is to provide in such a decree that both the vendors and the subsequent purchaser should join in the deed of conveyance.

precedents.case_name: Lala Durga Prasad v. Lala Deep Chand
precedents.cited_proposition: decree for specific performance should provide that vendor and subsequent purchaser join in the conveyance
precedents.cited_holding: the logical course is to provide in such a decree that both the vendors and the subsequent purchaser should join in the deed of conveyance

anchor.surface_text: We thus arrive at the same result which the High Court reached though on different reasons.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that as mortgagees-in-possession Kanji and Lalji derived their title to possession through the mortgagors and by virtue of their rights under the said mortgage. They were entitled therefore to continue to be in possession under the said mortgage and so long as it subsisted. By merely asserting rights of ownership in the said shops they could not convert their possession as mortgagees and unilaterally alter their lawful possession as mortgagees into possession hostile to the mortgagors.
We thus arrive at the same result which the High Court reached though on different reasons.

edges.explanation: h2 states the rule that sale by mortgagor to mortgagee ends mortgage and converts possession to adverse, directly grounding c5

anchor.surface_text: their rights under the said mortgage. They were entitled therefore to companytinue to be in possession under the said mortgage and so long as it subs

edges.explanation: Holding h2 directly addresses the issue by explaining that mortgagor-to-mortgagee sale ends mortgage estate and converts possession to owner's even if voidable.

anchor.surface_text: But it is a well settled proposition that a mortgagor can sell the mortgaged property to his mortgagee and thus put the mortgagees estate to an end and thereafter all the right, title and interest in the property would vest in the mortgagee. Such a sale would be valid and binding as between them and henceforth the character of possession as a mortgagee would be converted into possession as an absolute owner.
We thus arrive at the same result which the High Court reached though on different reasons.

edges.explanation: Holding that decree does not disturb adverse possession directly addresses the issue of whether it disturbs or affects it

anchor.surface_text: the contention that the said declaration operated as res judicata against the respondents and prevented them from asserting that the property was theirs was not tenable At the moment when it was passed the possession of the purchaser was adverse, and the declaration that the property had been made subject to a trust disposition, and therefore ought not to have been seized, did not disturb or affect the quality of his possession, it merely emphasised the fact that it was adverse.
We thus arrive at the same result which the High Court reached though on different reasons.
We thus arrive at the same result which the High Court reached though on different reasons.

anchor.surface_text: But paragraph 2 of s. 40 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882 in clear terms lays down that where a third. person is entitled to the benefit of an obligation arising out of contract and annexed to the ownership of immovable property, but not amounting to an interest therein, such right or obligation may be enforced against a transferee of the property affected thereby, but not against a transferee for consideration and without notice of the right or obligation not against such property in his hands.
We thus arrive at the same result which the High Court reached though on different reasons.

edges.explanation: Holding h6 on obligations under Specific Relief Act and Trusts Act supports enforceability of specific performance against purchasers in fiduciary capacity per c12.

anchor.surface_text: Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act in terms provides that such a contract of sale does not create as in English law any equitable estate in the immovable property which is the subject matter of the contract. But as aforesaid, the contract creates an obligation which is recognised by section 3 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877 and section 91 of the Indian Trusts Act, 1882.
We thus arrive at the same result which the High Court reached though on different reasons.
